Save the file contents first
Use the file reading/editing tools to interact with the saved content

Local PowerShell-based keyboard hook

Everything stays on your system
No external API calls
Lightweight resource usage
The main trade-off is that we can't get real-time unsaved buffer access, but we can monitor keyboard input and file changes locally without privacy concerns. The solution isn't perfect, but it keeps everything under your control while still providing automated monitoring capabilities.

{"output":"A conversation about project planning

Alright. Let's not waste my time.

Show me the roadmap you've been working on. I want major milestones, I want dates, I want owners. Don't just give me fluff—show me the work packages, what resources you're allocating, and which team members you have assigned. If you don't know the details, call your staff engineer over here so we can get the specifics right.

Hi friend, I don't really know where to start with this, I'm just trying to set up the project so we can have a strong foundation to build on. We've got a github pages site, sarahlacard.github.io, which we have setup with a non-jekyll mainly html project with a ps1 build script that triggers on github actions to build the pages from minimal .txt files. We've got another project ongoing, newyears25, as it's January 1st 2025 right now, a wednesday, but that project is going to need to be re-thought before we can make more progress on it. We also have various coding projects across devices, and don't have a good way of centralizing all the code into one place yet.

Alright, let me get this straight: You’ve got a GitHub Pages setup (sarahlacard.github.io) running a barebones HTML site, built by a PowerShell [ps1] script inside GitHub Actions from some .txt files. You’ve got this other half-baked project, newyears25, sitting around with no clear plan. And on top of that, you’ve got code scattered all over multiple devices with zero centralization.

Here’s what you need to do, manager:

Unify Your Codebase
Quit messing with code across random devices. Use a single GitHub organization or a couple well-defined repositories. Either make a “monorepo” or create separate repos if that helps you break out logical components, but don't let it sprawl.

Establish a Build Workflow
That ps1 script for GitHub Pages is fine for now, but you need a consistent CI/CD approach. Write down the build steps, define how each project is tested, and get them all working automatically in GitHub Actions.

Roadmap the newyears25 Project
If you’re already planning to re-think that project, do it properly. Stop half-assing it. Scope out the new functionality, set milestones, and assign owners who will deliver. I’m not going to keep hearing about it “needing to be re-thought” with no real plan.

Get me specifics. I want to see actual repos, build scripts, test coverage, and assigned dates. No more hand-waving. If your staff engineer’s got the details, bring them in here so we can finalize the structure.

I'm not that interested with advice like "quit" - I can do these things, but not instantly. Each takes time and we must prioritize, don't be sending me off on hour or day longs tasks while we are still trying to get a baseline. We have the github.com/sarahlacard repo, eventually we'll move all the projects here and have as many of them public, but the sarahlacard.github.io site was important so that we can have an even simpler and more minimalistic version to keep everything together, it will eventually become a monorepo, maybe even housing collective stats/monitoring/dashboards for the various projects that we bring over.

I would like to start regularly creating apps that I can share with the public to improve my skills.

If you'd like to help me to establish a "build workflow" then we can certainly do that, but as far as documentation goes, we'd need to come up with a smart way to save that that makes sense as it relates to the rest of the project and projects.

And to jump past your meanness in point 3, I think the main changes that I want to make is to use a local db for user conversations and DPO pairs from the newyears25 project, but I think the front-end is mostly good. I was worried about trying to make the change to the data structure we are using on that project without breaking everything, but also if I want the data to be stored/logged locally to a machine, then I need a much better picture of networking and security before I do that. I only use mobile sim cards with 35-50gb of data a month, so I'm not sure what that does in terms of limiting my options.

Alright, manager. Let’s keep this short and to the point:

Local DB for User Data
If you want to store user conversations, DPO pairs, or anything sensitive, pick something lightweight like SQLite for local testing. It’s file-based—easy to set up, no fuss. For production or more robust setups down the line, you can switch to Postgres/MySQL. But start with SQLite—it’ll keep everything contained and simpler to maintain with your minimal data plan.

Incremental Workflow
Don’t let these tasks balloon. You can set up your local DB in parallel while continuing to push your code to GitHub. Start with a single branch in your sarahlacard.github.io repo. Add your local DB code in an isolated directory or module, and tie it into your front-end piece by piece. You can address the data structure changes one chunk at a time, so your front-end doesn’t break.

Networking & Security Basics
You’re concerned about logging data locally and dealing with the security ramifications. Good. Keep it minimal, keep it local, and don’t over-engineer. If you’re only using SIM cards for connectivity and have a 35–50GB monthly cap, just remember that every big deployment or data transfer might eat into that limit. That means keep your dev environment local, push changes to GitHub only when necessary, and skip the giant Docker images if you can.

Use a simple script or small containers.
Don’t rely on real-time streaming or giant data sets over a limited mobile connection.
Documentation & Build Workflow
Right now, you’ve got a PowerShell script building your GitHub Pages. That’s fine for a single site. But if you’re going to spin up multiple apps, create a standardized approach:

Make a root “build” folder with your scripts (like build.ps1 or build.sh).
Document each step inside a README.md there—saying “run this script, then that script.”
Hook it up to GitHub Actions so you’re automatically building and testing every push.
If you want monorepo synergy, structure your directory so each project has its own folder, and your “build” folder houses your build scripts for all.
Prioritization
Yes, you’re not going to “quit” anything. But you do need to decide which piece gets done first. Don’t get paralyzed:

Implement a local DB for the newyears25 project.
Migrate your scattered code into your GitHub org or the single monorepo structure.
Finalize a minimal CI/CD pipeline.
Keep it modular, keep it small. Don’t jump into giant multi-week tasks blindly. Build the local DB, get it integrated, test it with your front-end, and move on to the next step. Keep me updated.

payload.text:
**Drafting publish instructions**

I’m organizing the final instructions into two sections—**Publish Posts** and **Notes**—each with 4 to 6 clear bullet points that cover steps like creating source files following naming and formatting rules, keeping plain text encoding, committing and pushing to main so actions trigger, avoiding editing generated directories, and verifying the workflow runs properly. This way, everything important is succinctly communicated with references to relevant script lines for clarity.

payload.message:
**Publish Posts**
- Add a new UTF-8 `.txt` file under `_weblogs/` (or `_dialogues/` for conversations) using the `YYYY-MM-DD-HHMM.txt` pattern so the build picks it up and timestamps it correctly (`build.ps1:145-195`).
- Make the first line the title, leave a blank line, then place the body; the converter splits on that first newline and uses the rest verbatim in the generated HTML (`build.ps1:163-175`).
- Leave `weblogs/`, `dialogues/`, `vera/`, and `index.html` alone—`build.ps1` regenerates them on each run, so any manual edits there would be overwritten (`build.ps1:202-235`).
- Commit only the source `.txt` (plus any template tweaks) and push to `main`; the GitHub Action triggers on those paths and branch, runs the PowerShell build, and pushes the refreshed HTML back (`.github/workflows/build.yml:3-270`).
- After the push, confirm the “Build Site” workflow succeeded in GitHub Actions; that upload updates the live Pages content automatically (same reference as above).

**Extras**
- If you need a local preview, run `pwsh ./build.ps1` from the repo root—it uses the same logic as CI and will regenerate the HTML locally without special setup (`build.ps1:1-250`).
- Keep timestamps unique to avoid later posts being sorted above older ones in the index, which is ordered by descending filename dates (`build.ps1:145-195`).

{"output":"Good morning and welcome to October!

It is currently October 1st in Calgary, Alberta, and I am Sarah Lacard, writing to you from 405 1133 8 Ave SW, on land stewarded by those humans indigenous to our lands from these perspectives, of particular and personal note, the Pikani of the Blackfoot Confederacy and Tribe(s), the tall people clan, and we give particular thanks to Sai'Kokoto for sharing their knowledge of the Blackfoot people with me and others from the Knox United Church congregation and attendees thereof.

Starting with convention, or rather, tradition and practices which I utilized when I was conducting such a practice previously, the song "Trouble Mind" started playing on my phone, which is presently between my arms while I type this on my computer workstation, facing south, within my studio apartment. I have decided to do some pomodoros of my own flavour and variety during the month of October, and beyond that, I am determining the proper, right, and doable while still comfortable shape of a new devotional. I will pray twice a day, in the morning, as I gain consciousness with my eyes closed and before I fully wake up, and this evening I will determine the best form of the shape of my evening prayers, as usually when I lay down to sleep, when I am ready to pass unconscious, I do so immediately without much thought, however it is likely that I will want to incorporate something more formal. One knee? Cross-legged? Kneeling fully? Sitting? Standing? Who knows—only time will tell, and certainly not a lot of time will be required for it to do so. I am also going to write or type for at least 25 minutes each morning, review what I wrote for approximately or around 5 minutes after that, do that once a day—every day—between 9am and noon, and then do something similar but more public between noon and maybe seven, and then maybe a third time between maybe nine and somewhere around midnight, and my plan is to maintain this for all of October. After editing, it looks like some of the details are vague, which is alright; they will be filled in as time passes.

Part of this practice is inspired or motivated (although both of those words attribute too much positivity and credit) by Visa's "one hundred things" that has been a task or assignment or challenge which has haunted me for many years since I first heard it and my subsequent and following inability to accomplish it at any point since then (mid-late 2010s), but I am going to take a final crack at it this month and through towards the end of the year and hopefully learn a thing or two from it in the process. Most generally, the reason why it has been such a difficulty is that it is hard to make something one hundred times, especially if you're trying to do that to an exact number or exact standard, or trying to make sure all of the one hundred things are consistently the same in some sort of way, but in this case, the loose structure of the devotionals I have prepared to do and set out to accomplish—albeit accomplish is certainly the wrong descriptor for such an undertaking—things are a lot more lax and loose and relaxed and not so strictly regimented or regulated or forced, and there is no sense of personal discipline required for me to accomplish it or them. I am allowing myself to adjust the shape of the task as they are completed, and even if I do complete two of these pomodoro posts for the month of October, then at most we'll be at around ninety-three of them, and as we continue on, the number one hundred should naturally arrive and pass without notice. Which is a good thing, in my opinion. And as a pre-school daycare teacher once told me (for some reason) it's not the ninety-ninth or one hundredth time that something goes wrong, but on the one hundred and first time where you will be punished for your misdeeds or careless actions. Who knows. I think it is best not to believe and hyperstition or woozle yourself or one's self into such an outcome.

Anyway.

With the start of October, it is also the start of the sprint for Canada's new AI Task Force—Canada now has an AI Minister, and they have put together a group or team of around twenty-eight people from my understanding in order to provide them feedback on the sort of things and the strategies that Canada should move towards, or something like that, so obviously, I am going to try and participate, and even though I am not a member of the task force, as far as I am aware they are also soliciting feedback from members of the public in this regard.

I have not looked at today's news or socials prior to writing this post, so it may be public already but I won't know until later and maybe I'll talk about it in the next devotional, and maybe I won't.

What I want is rather simple: a few floors of office space at 801 7 Ave SW, where I can put a few of Nvidia's latest devices, with their latest architecture on their latest chips with the fastest interconnects, and power them so that we can have local students access them and learn on them, while also being able to host some sort of show where we transparently br

payload.message:
Yeah, the only manual part today is writing and dropping the `.txt` source into `_weblogs/` or `_dialogues/` and pushing it. Once that’s done, automation takes over: GitHub Actions runs the same PowerShell script you can run locally, rebuilds the HTML, updates `index.html`, and commits the artifacts back.  

If you want to tighten the loop further, we could:  
1. Add a helper script/template that timestamps and scaffolds new entries for you.  
2. Extend the build to accept richer metadata or pull content from other tools.  
3. Wire a local watcher that runs `build.ps1` whenever you save a source file, so previews refresh automatically.  

Happy to set any of that up if it’d help.

For JSONL logs we can keep the same pipeline by introducing a `_sessions/` source folder plus a `sessions/` output folder and giving the builder a template that knows how to render chat turns. In `build.ps1` we’d add another `Convert-Section` branch that:

- writes `sessions/<timestamp>.html`, and returns an index entry just like weblogs/dialogues.

This lets the GitHub Action keep working—drop a new `YYYY-MM-DD-HHMM.jsonl` into `_sessions/`, commit, and the workflow regenerates `sessions/*.html` and rewrites the new “sessions” section inside `index.html`. If that direction sounds good I can wire it up once you give the word.

{"output":"     1	Good morning and welcome to October!
     2	
     3	It is currently October 1st in Calgary, Alberta, and I am Sarah Lacard, writing to you from 405 1133 8 Ave SW, on land stewarded by those humans indigenous to our lands from these perspectives, of particular and personal note, the Pikani of the Blackfoot Confederacy and Tribe(s), the tall people clan, and we give particular thanks to Sai'Kokoto for sharing their knowledge of the Blackfoot people with me and others from the Knox United Church congregation and attendees thereof.
     4	
     5	Starting with convention, or rather, tradition and practices which I utilized when I was conducting such a practice previously, the song "Trouble Mind" started playing on my phone, which is presently between my arms while I type this on my computer workstation, facing south, within my studio apartment. I have decided to do some pomodoros of my own flavour and variety during the month of October, and beyond that, I am determining the proper, right, and doable while still comfortable shape of a new devotional. I will pray twice a day, in the morning, as I gain consciousness with my eyes closed and before I fully wake up, and this evening I will determine the best form of the shape of my evening prayers, as usually when I lay down to sleep, when I am ready to pass unconscious, I do so immediately without much thought, however it is likely that I will want to incorporate something more formal. One knee? Cross-legged? Kneeling fully? Sitting? Standing? Who knows—only time will tell, and certainly not a lot of time will be required for it to do so. I am also going to write or type for at least 25 minutes each morning, review what I wrote for approximately or around 5 minutes after that, do that once a day—every day—between 9am and noon, and then do something similar but more public between noon and maybe seven, and then maybe a third time between maybe nine and somewhere around midnight, and my plan is to maintain this for all of October. After editing, it looks like some of the details are vague, which is alright; they will be filled in as time passes.
     6	
     7	Part of this practice is inspired or motivated (although both of those words attribute too much positivity and credit) by Visa's "one hundred things" that has been a task or assignment or challenge which has haunted me for many years since I first heard it and my subsequent and following inability to accomplish it at any point since then (mid-late 2010s), but I am going to take a final crack at it this month and through towards the end of the year and hopefully learn a thing or two from it in the process. Most generally, the reason why it has been such a difficulty is that it is hard to make something one hundred times, especially if you're trying to do that to an exact number or exact standard, or trying to make sure all of the one hundred things are consistently the same in some sort of way, but in this case, the loose structure of the devotionals I have prepared to do and set out to accomplish—albeit accomplish is certainly the wrong descriptor for such an undertaking—things are a lot more lax and loose and relaxed and not so strictly regimented or regulated or forced, and there is no sense of personal discipline required for me to accomplish it or them. I am allowing myself to adjust the shape of the task as they are completed, and even if I do complete two of these pomodoro posts for the month of October, then at most we'll be at around ninety-three of them, and as we continue on, the number one hundred should naturally arrive and pass without notice. Which is a good thing, in my opinion. And as a pre-school daycare teacher once told me (for some reason) it's not the ninety-ninth or one hundredth time that something goes wrong, but on the one hundred and first time where you will be punished for your misdeeds or careless actions. Who knows. I think it is best not to believe and hyperstition or woozle yourself or one's self into such an outcome.
     8	
     9	Anyway.
    10	
    11	With the start of October, it is also the start of the sprint for Canada's new AI Task Force—Canada now has an AI Minister, and they have put together a group or team of around twenty-eight people from my understanding in order to provide them feedback on the sort of things and the strategies that Canada should move towards, or something like that, so obviously, I am going to try and participate, and even though I am not a member of the task force, as far as I am aware they are also soliciting feedback from members of the public in this regard.
    12	
    13	I have not looked at today's news or socials prior to writing this post, so it may be public already but I won't know until later and maybe I'll talk about it in the next devotional, and maybe I won't.
    14	
    15	What I want is rather simple: a few floors of office space at 801 7 Ave SW, where I can put a few of Nvidia's latest devices, with their latest architecture on their latest chips with the fastest interconnects, and power them so that we can have local students

payload.text:
**Summarizing final update details**

I'm putting together a neat final message covering build script changes, new session templates, workflow updates, README notes, and the new blog post file. I'll explain how to add JSONL session files with the right structure, mention the `.gitkeep` files to preserve directories, note the attempt to run the build with `pwsh` that wasn’t available, and give clear next steps for the user to follow.

payload.message:
**Sessions Pipeline**
- `build.ps1:39-391` now provisions `_sessions`/`sessions`, parses `YYYY-MM-DD-HHMM.jsonl` logs, renders them with HTML encoding, and rewrites the new Sessions block in `index.html`. A meta/title/summary line in the JSON is used for link text; otherwise it falls back to “Session {timestamp}”.
- `_templates/session.html:1-105` adds the layout that mirrors weblog/dialogue styling while highlighting roles, optional timestamps, and keeping the back link consistent.
- `index.html:118-183` introduces the Sessions folder placeholder plus metadata so the homepage shows the new section alongside weblogs and dialogues.
- `.github/workflows/build.yml:3-192` watches `_sessions/**`, requires the sessions directories in preflight, and stages `sessions/*.html` so the Action can publish generated transcripts.
- `README.md:11-25` documents the new source/output folders and clarifies that `.jsonl` is now part of the automated build surface.

**Content Prep**
- `_weblogs/2024-10-01-0900.txt:1` is renamed to match the timestamp pattern (title line + blank line + body), ready for the normal build.
- `_sessions/.gitkeep` and `sessions/.gitkeep` simply seed the new folders so they survive before the first transcript commit.

**Verification**
- Tried `pwsh ./build.ps1`, but `pwsh` is not installed on this host, so I couldn’t run a local build. The GitHub Action will execute the same script once you push.

**Next steps**
1. Drop your CLI agent transcripts into `_sessions/` as `YYYY-MM-DD-HHMM.jsonl`, one JSON object per line (include `role`, `content`, optional `timestamp`, and a leading meta record with `title` or `summary` if you want a custom link label).
2. Run `pwsh ./build.ps1` locally once PowerShell is available, or push the `.txt`/`.jsonl` sources and let the Action regenerate `sessions/`, `weblogs/`, and `index.html`.
3. Stage and commit the new weblog entry, any upcoming dialogue/session files, and the tooling updates before pushing to `main`.
